content: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section, SEC. 45G, which provides a clean-fuel credit for businesses in nonattainment areas. The new section SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses based on clean-fuel property and clean-burning fuel use. Qualified vehicle property costs and qualified refueling property costs are included in the clean-fuel property credit. The new section SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses based on clean-fuel property and clean-burning fuel use. The credit is limited based on the type of motor vehicle used, with maximum amounts ranging from $2,000 to $50,000 depending on the vehicle's specifications. The new section SEC. 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses based on clean-fuel property and clean-burning fuel use. The credit is limited based on the type of motor vehicle used, with maximum amounts ranging from $2,000 to $50,000 depending on the vehicle's specifications. Qualified clean-fuel vehicle property excludes motor vehicles propelled by non-clean-burning fuel. Qualified refueling property costs are defined for tax purposes. The term 'qualified refueling property costs' refers to amounts paid by eligible businesses for clean-fuel vehicle refueling property placed in service in a nonattainment area during the taxable year. The aggregate cost taken into account is limited to $100,000 or the cost of the property, whichever is less. The cost of the property is reduced by the amount previously taken into account under different clauses for preceding taxable years and with respect to property placed in service. The clean-burning fuel use credit is 50 cents for each gasoline gallon equivalent of clean-burning fuel used by an eligible business to propel qualified clean-fuel vehicle property. The term 'clean-burning fuel' is defined by section 179A, including compressed fuel. Special rules from section 179A(b)(2) apply. The term 'gasoline gallon equivalent' is defined as the amount of clean burning fuel with a Btu content of 114,000. An 'eligible business' includes qualified entities and businesses located outside nonattainment areas for clean fuel use credit purposes. The Clean Air Act defines a nonattainment area for clean-fuel vehicle property credit. No double benefit is allowed for expenses already deducted or credited. The clean-fuel credit is now part of the general business credit under section 38 of the tax code. The Clean Air Act prohibits double benefits for clean-fuel expenses by denying deductions equal to the clean-fuel credit determined under section 45G. The credit can be used against regular and minimum tax liabilities. Special rules apply to the clean fuels credit, where it is treated separately from other credits and the limitation on the credit is reduced by the amount allowed for the taxable year. The clean fuels credit is defined as the credit allowable under subsection (a) by reason of section 45G. Conforming amendments include adding the clean fuels credit to certain sections of the tax code. Additionally, there is a limitation on carryback for the clean fuels credit. The tax code is amended to restrict the carryback of the clean fuels credit before the effective date of section 45G. Additionally, a deduction for the clean fuels credit is added to certain sections of the tax code. Additionally, a deduction for the clean fuels credit is added to certain sections of the tax code, inserting a new item after section 45F. The tax code amendments restrict the carryback of the clean fuels credit before the effective date of section 45G, which applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2002.
